body_html:
Although the PyYAML documentation site suggests that from yaml import CLoader as <insert name> is possible, I could not perform it. That is a reason for the try failing. This has been reported as well: yaml/pyyaml#108

I believe that the except should have this instead:

from yaml import Loader as YamlLoader

In fact when I did this:

>>> import yaml as y
>>> y.__with_libyaml__
False

This indicates that the CLoader import didn't happen in PyYAML itself.
body_text:
Although the PyYAML documentation site suggests that from yaml import CLoader as <insert name> is possible, I could not perform it. That is a reason for the try failing. This has been reported as well: yaml/pyyaml#108
I believe that the except should have this instead:
from yaml import Loader as YamlLoader
In fact when I did this:
>>> import yaml as y
>>> y.__with_libyaml__
False
This indicates that the CLoader import didn't happen in PyYAML itself.
body:
Although the PyYAML documentation site suggests that `from yaml import CLoader as <insert name>` is possible, I could not perform it. That is a reason for the `try` failing. This has been reported as well: https://github.com/yaml/pyyaml/issues/108

I believe that the `except` should have this instead:
```python
from yaml import Loader as YamlLoader
```

In fact when I did this:
```python
>>> import yaml as y
>>> y.__with_libyaml__
False
```

This indicates that the `CLoader` import didn't happen in PyYAML itself.
